content.body: i'm tracking down more stuff about mime sniffing
With all this sniffing, has anybody worked out what mimes smell like yet?

The Barth paper contains the claim "Once one browser vendor implements content sniffing, the other browser vendors are forced to follow suit or risk losing market share [1]", where [1] is not some study of market share of browser vendor behavior, but just some mozilla bug report: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=175848
well, seems like a pretty smelly reference
it's a pretty astounding claim, really, that browser market share depends on content type sniffing
rather than, say, performance, ease of use, conformant behavior when confronted with actually properly labelled content
It's a pretty astounding claim that it doesn't
it doesn't what?
Depend on content sniffing
i mean that it's a more significant factor than 100 other things
It doesn't have to be
It just has to be a sufficienty significant factor
Which it is

it's the standard, if the browser doesn't show the web page (properly), or shows it in some broken way, the user tries a different browser, if the other browser appears to "work", the user sticks with it.
how significant a factor is it?
Indeed, users couldn't care less about whether content is properly labelled or not
more significant than performance, pretty GUI, brand name, etc.
I think its significance is about 0.18
masinter: I don't know how to put in on a scale.
i mean, 1% of the population would switch from FirefOx to Chrome if Chrome sniffed and FireFox didn't, even if Firefox was faster and implemented more other features?
none of that matters if the browser "breaks" from the user's perception.
It is significant enough that it has to be there
exactly this response has to be there?
It is believed by browser vendors to be significant enough that it has to be there
i mean, this is a major "feature" and the justification is that someone read a bug report?
Philip`: Those two statements are roughly equivalent
which product manager would back that up?

"oh this browser doesn't work with my bank, I'll try another browser, or ask my friends which browser they use and try that. oh look this other browsers seems to 'work' with my bank, and is fine with other sites too, I'll stick to it."
which banks have misconfigured web servers?
which banks don't?
masinter: Working with the web is a major feature. In a web browser
sure, some user sites, c'mon tantek
misconfigured HTTP, HTML you name it

The theoretically quantifiable figure is probably more like: If a million happy Firefox users try out Chrome, how many abandon Chrome because one of the websites they like to visit fails to work in Chrome (due to sniffing differences)
you're making circular definitions
know any bank sites that validate? good luck.
name one, Tantek, that has misconfigured mime types?
this isn't about validation, it's about content-type sniffing
nope - all the same
my left shoe isn't configured properly either
it's all about compat
tantek, what is all the same?
to the user it's all the same. my browser is broken.
hmmm, argument by assertion?
doesn't matter whether the pipe or pipe-fitting is broken
masinter: Since banks typically require a login it is rather hard to verify whether they have configured their server correctly
and experience. i've built browsers.
i understand the nature of the argument, tantek, and repeating it doesn't help
and usertested browser useres.
users even
|<tantek> "oh this browser doesn't work with my bank, I'll try another browser,
this is one of those "duh" things to anyone who builds browsers.
tantek: indeed
"duh" "duh"

well, it's a "duh" argument indeed that if you make claims about banks and user behavior and market share that you have to have more than saying "well, duh, we're right and you're wrong nyah nyah nyah"
masinter: market research data that i've seen from two different browser vendors puts compatibility with sites as the number #1 reason for switching browsers
literally above all else
more important than security, than having extensions/add-ons, than having features, than speed, anything
well, why is the citation in http://www.adambarth.com/papers/2009/barth-caballero-song.pdf to a mozilla bug report?
I would say that Hixie's data matches my experience
what else would you cite? browser vendors aren't going to publish the data telling their competition why they are losing customers!
I mean, if there were any market research data, why cite the bug report?
i don't think i've seen any of these numbers publicly
oh, well, you could cite "John Q. Product Manager, Personal Communication"
masinter: I doubt the market research data mentions content type sniffing explicitly
jgraham: so you have any personal experience with content-type sniffing?
i was just looking at the table again, and noticing content-type sniffing for application/postscript
masinter: It's not something I have worked on directly. So only the amount of experience you get by osmosis doing general browser QA
and trying to figure out why a user would switch browsers if the browser they were using wouldn't sniff application/postscript
i mean, since it doesn't help you any to sniff postscript, because most people don't have a postscript interpreter installed anyway
If I clicked a link to a .ps file of an academic paper and got a load of gibberish text, I'd be pretty unhappy

masinter, perhaps Adobe could fund a development experiment to create a "conformant" (but real-world-web-site-content-breaking) browser (e.g. fork Moz or WebKit and rm all the compat behavior) and see if anyone bothered to use it as a primary browser.
so how does the market share loss argument (which is unsubstantiated) even apply for postscript?
so you'd want it to infer application/octet-stream?
masinter: Well presumably the type of people looking at postscript documents have postscript interpreters installed
why are you making normative requirements based on presumptions?
isn't doing anything
you don't support making content-type sniffing a normative requirement?
Yes, but that's not what you said
ok, let's go break this down
Or, at least, I assumed "making normative requirements" refered specifically to the postscript sniffing
do you support http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-abarth-mime-sniff-01 and the HTML specification's normative reference to that as something HTML interpreters MUST follow?
In general, yes. Possibly some details could be altered, I don't know

and, in particular, the requirement in section 3 that the 'sniffed type' for documents labeled text/plain should follow the sniffing algorithm such that data that looks like postscript MUST be treated as application/postscript, even though it is text/plain?
what justification is sufficient for altering details?
http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2005/02/01/364581.aspx

masinter: Details can be altered if a) they don't match current practice and implementors refuse to change to match the spec or b) there is a compelling (to implementors) case made that the detail can be changed without adversly affecting marketshare
yes, i read that blog but it doesn't answer my question about what you think the criteria is for following exactly what IE happened to do?
and how do you measure "adversely affecting marketshare"?
i'm just wondering whether "compatibility" is taken as covering a multitude of sins where what was really asked for is much more limited
masinter: That ballis in the court of those trying to change the details
I don't know a-priori what arguments would be compelling to indicate that a specific change would not adversly affect compatibility
"ball is in the court" metaphor assumes some ownership of the court, doesn't it?
(but obvious things would be studies indicating that a particular part of the sniffing did not apply to a significant number of pages)
after all, the internet draft doesn't match current practice, for good reason
well, since there's never been any evidence that anything besides text/plain => html matters, and even then, only for a limited number of sites
and since browser content-type sniffing isn't uniform anyway
I guess you mean that you haven't come across the evidence.
I would be very surprised if that was the case
masinter, do you have a test case URL that demonstrates non-uniform browser content-type sniffing?
i thought XML wasn't uniform
no XML is worse, it's draconian
is going to bed now
looking for XML test case

tantek: there are lots of areas of content-type sniffing that aren't uniform -- it leads to security bugs, it leads to an arms race increasing how much is sniffed, and it leads to a general low level of interop; that's why I, and now Adam, are trying to specify this.
tantek you think all browsers sniff XML from text/plain uniformly?
tantek: we want to nail it does so that this kind of crap can be uniformly implemented and stop spreading like a cancer

yeah, i think you're looking at the wrong end of the telescope, and that every case of sniffing actually needs to be justified by "some users really care" rather than the general principle of "if IE did it, we're going to slavishly follow"
i think it's a bad idea to sniff PDF too, for that matter, although Adobe security just said it didn't matter to them much
which IE followed vaguely from "if Netscape did it, we're going to follow in order to not 'break' sites"
found a site earlier today that serves up an svg image as text/plain...
Hixie, I think your approach to this problem is reasonable.
but if something's labeled text/plain but looks like PDF it should still be treated as text/plain, because if the MIME type is broken, probably something else is too
would like to see a path forward out of the compat mess.
tantek: are you saying my approach is unreasonable?
masinter: the doc adam is working on is so far removed from what IE does that your suggesting that it has any resemblence to it belies your ignorance of the subject
oh c'mon Hixie
masinter, no, I can see the reason behind your approach as well. but it's just less practical.
now you're gonna start calling me names
Jane, you ignorant ... etc.
masinter: well, stop trying to troll us then
discussing a subject at your convenience is trolling?
everybody who disagrees with you is a troll?
masinter: accusing us of following 'general principle of "if IE did it, we're going to slavishly follow"' is either ignorant or a troll. Which is it?
we spent quite a while at the TAG meeting talking about sniffing, and i thought it was worth just, you know, talking about it
How many people on the TAG have actually built and shipped a browser?
you don't make any provocative statements, do you?
(in this decade)
(not a rhetorical question)
in #whatwg? i make provocative statements all the time :-)
i think it is a pretty irrelevant question, isn't it?
not at all, it's the difference between architectural handwaving and shipping software brutally tested by a market
oh, ok, 'slavishly' was wrong, how about 'without careful consideration of actual user benefit'?
tantek, are you saying the TAG does 'architectural handwaving'?
says this as someone who has done both (handwaving and shipping)
waves his hand to no effect
masinter: seriously? you think we're ignoring the benefits of users?
no, i didn't say you were 'ignoring' it
http://www.igmetall-eisenach.de/pressemitteilungen/pressemitteilung_29_08_05_14_07 doesn't look very good for me in Firefox
masinter: what exactly do you think our motivations are? just to make the web a horrible place?
i'm just asking about the end user benefit of application/postscript?
masinter: so you're saying we're incompetent?
oh c'mon
we don't carefully consider stuff?
in this particular instance, i'm asking for the benefit of your careful consideration
what is, please, the end-user benefit of content-type sniffing application/postscript?
no, you're just chain-accusing us of random evils
really, i came with a specific question about a specific use case
i'm not interested in discussing technical work with people who go from insulting me to trying to act all innocent by asking technical questions
and i got platitudes about market share and who has shipped a browser
i'm not insulting you, and asking questions and criticizing the specification you wrote is not directed against you
you're not insulting me? let's see. in the last
10, 20 minutes
no, i really am not
you've said:
* that's we're slavishly following a principle of "if IE did it, we're going to follow"
* that we don't consider users carefully
well, read what the barth paper says
* that we're giving you platitudes when we're giving you our actual reasoning
I didn't say that you didn't consider users in general, but i can't see it in the particular case
"Once one browser vendor implements content sniffing,
the other browser vendors are forced to follow suit or risk
losing market share"
how would you interpret that sentence, from http://www.adambarth.com/papers/2009/barth-caballero-song.pdf
once one browser vendor implements X, the other browser vendors are forced to follow suit
what is that ? Or do you think the paper is wrong?
now "one browser" doesn' mean Amaya, of course, it means the unmentionable Internet Exploder
if you want to ask about something adam wrote, i recommend asking adam
so was this just academic hyperbole on Barth's part?
so you have no opinion about this logic? It isn't the justification for content-type sniffing?
when I asked about the content-type sniffing and research, it's the paper Adam pointed me to
i've already given the justification for mime sniffing in this very conversation, let me repaste it:
i mean, we could go back to trading email but it's better just to talk this out, you take what i'm saying and make it personal

<Hixie> there are lots of areas of content-type sniffing that aren't uniform -- it leads to security bugs, it leads to an arms race increasing how much is sniffed, and it leads to a general low level of interop; that's why I, and now Adam, are trying to specify this.
i take what you're saying and make it personal when you insult my competence, yes
i'm not talking about you, i'm talking about specs and documents
and we're better off to focus on that, it was bad enough that mpilgrim wanted to tell me i was ugly
saying that'we slavishly following things, saying that we write specs without "carefully considering user benefits", that's personal
wait, i was talking about this sentence in the barth draft
"forced to follow suit"? What is that?
you mean his paper?
it wasn't about you or Adam, it was what "browser vendors" felt they were "compelled to do"
"slavishly follow" == "forced to follow suit"
you just said slavishly follow was wrong!
i think that was legitimate english use that was not about you at all, it was about the presumption of what browser vendors felt they had to do
now you're saying it's right?
no, the fact that browser vendors may believe they are forced to follow suite -- i don't dispute that they believe that
but you said we were slavishly following IE
which is completely wrong
i just think they are wrong, there are lots of things they could do besides "follow suit"
looks back

"yeah, i think you're looking at the wrong end of the telescope, and            that every case of sniffing actually needs to be justified by "some            users really care" rather than the general principle of "if IE did            it, we're going to slavishly follow"
that's what i said
you also said "oh, ok, 'slavishly' was wrong"
and you assumed that i was talking about you having this general principle, but certainly it's clear you odn't
let's start this conversation over because you've contradicted yourself so many times i no longer know what to ignore and what not to ignore
hi larry, how are you? how can i help you today?
well, ok
what's the justification for sniffing application/postscript ?>
i know IE does it, and maybe some other browsers too, but there doesn't actually seem to be any end-user benefit, and potentially some harm instead
seems like a bad idea
well, i don't know that IE does it, i presume that
I'm assuming every bit of sniffing that IS done in draf-barth is becasue someone else already does it, and probably someone else = IE
is there a specific end-user benefit for that?

I believe the justification for having sniffing for application/postscript in the spec is that when i created that table, I copied the algorithms in Mozills's codebase that were unambiguously beneficial to users.
how were they "unambigiously beneficial"?
since in this case the benefit seems mysterious

(IE really has very little bearing on what the content-sniffing draft says, in practice, because we used what the other browsers found themselves forced to implement as a guide for what was actually necessary, and what was not)
i mean, just because someone implemented it in Mozilla doesn't mean it is unambiguously beneficial
(IE basically ignores Content-Type 99% of the time, so following IE would basically mean throwing out most of the MIME mechanisms)
right? You're not assuming that "since Mozilla did it, it must be right", of course
looks at adam's draft to make sure he's talking about the right table
"   I copied the algorithms in Mozills's codebase that were unambiguously         beneficial to users." -- how did you determine "unambiguously beneficial"?

this sniffing is beneficial because if a user finds a page with no MIME type, or the MIME types unknown/unknown, application/unknown, or */*, or if the user loads a text/plain page that is clearly not text/plain (since it contains raw binary), and if the page is in fact a postscript page, it's more useful to show the postscript in an interpreted fashion than expose the user to the source of the file.
in practice, in particular, users prefer browsers that allow them to print the resulting files, rather than show the source
what postscript interpreters to people have?
and market research data (not published) shows this kind of thing (though not necessarily this specific case) is the #1 reason for users to switch browsers.
most operating systems don't come with postscript interpreters, and when people install them, the ones i've used -- most of them over the years -- don't do the right thing anyway
so trying to fire up something that isn't installed, or something that is installed and does the wrong thing -- how does that help anyone?
generally, users specifically opting to view postscript pages have postscript interpreters, i would imagine (though this is not based on any hard data)
it doesn't do the wrong thing, actually -- it will typically offer the file to be saved to disk
which is reliably more useful to users than showing the content raw on the screen
(I believe most Linuxes have PS interpreters by default)
do they, Philip?
masinter: I believe so
i'm just interested in the "unambiguously beneficial" bit
the other example where type sniffing seems harmful is interpreting text/plain as text/xml even if it's mal-formed
what would the benefit be of _not_ either offering the file to download or opening the file in a PS interpreter?
(e.g. okular (KDE) and evince (Gnome) both support PDF and PS and some other formats)
i don't believe text/plain is _ever_ sniffed as text/xml by adam's draft
it would be better to assume application/octet-stream than application/postscript
that would be a security risk
masinter: why?
because just because it starts with a few bytes of the header is no indication that the rest of the file is valid
it's a heuristic at best, and the consequences are ugly. at least with text/html you can View Source and see the original text/plain
and you're not turning text into application
wait, which case are you talking about?
no, application/octet-stream is lower capability than text/plain
and much lower than application/postscript. It means that *no* automatic processing should happen
text/plain containing binary being interpreted as application/postscript, you think that would be better interpreted as application/octet-stream?
better not being interpreted
since application/octet-stream is the explicit "type unknown" mime type
i'm not sure i understand what you're saying browsers should do and in what case
well, if we can agree that a change is in order because there's a problem, then working out the solution is next
which case are you talking about?
there are a lot of ways in which browsers could respond to a heuristically determined server configuration error, only one of which is to automatically assume that because the heuristic triggered
well, i noticed application/postscript and thought it was worth understanding the justification for that in the current draft
i thought it was worth at least talking this out first, don't you? would you have preferred to wait for some formal objection with a line-by-line analysis first?

so you're proposing that text/plain-labeled content, containing undisplayable binary and starting with the postscript signature, instead of being interpreted as application/postscript, would be better interpreted as application/octet-stream?
i'm jsut trying to understand your proposal
i haven't made a proposal yet, and don't want to make one offhand
oh. what did you mean by "it would be better to assume application/octet-stream than application/postscript" then?
well, that would be better, but i don't know if it would be best
it's worth examining what all of the alternatives are to the current proposed behavior before making a concrete proposal, isn't it?

so you're saying that in your opinion, if the UA finds text/plain-labeled content containing undisplayable binary and starting with the postscript signature, it would be better (though maybe not best) if, instead of being interpreted as application/postscript, it was interpreted as application/octet-stream?
well, "interpreted as application/octet-stream" is pretty misleading
it would be better if no automatic interpretation were offered, and the user instead prompted to save the file
that's what "interpreted as application/octet-stream" amounts to in practice
that's also what "interpreted as application/postscript" amounts to in practice, unless the user has a viewer, which i understand (based on masinter's comments) is not the common case

well, i think i understand that, not sure everyone who reads this dialog would know that for sure, and "rather than interpreting as X, interpret as Y" where X is the best guess -- sounds like an odd proposal
oh i thought you said Y in this case was the better guess
well, and the possibility that Linux systems often have postscript interpreters, maybe Firefox on Linux does something interesting?
the only harm to users in not doing sniffing is that they always are offered to save the file without invoking the displayer automatically
no, not at all
in this case, not doing sniffing would mean showing the undisplayable binary content to the user
why is it undisplayable?
my emacs displays binary data just fine, and so does notepad
the file in this example is "text/plain-labeled content containing undisplayable binary and starting with the postscript signature", that's the case we're talking about
yes, exactly
well, you're saying "undisplayable" and I think it is "ugly"
but most systems display it
and it might be a general heuristic about text/plain data with ugly (or undisaplayable) binary
this only gets invoked with files containing control characters that are by definition invalid in text/plain
Safari has an inline PostScript viewer
fires up windows safari
not the Windows version
(yet, anyway)
Mac Safari displays PostScript and PDF files natively in the browser window (with ability to download or open in external viewer provided)
switches to mac
the reason I cite this is because, for Safari at least, sniffing as "application/octet-stream" vs "application/postscript" would result in significantly different behavior
contra Hixie's earlier remark
iirc, the case larry was saying that not sniffing would be better for is the case where the signature is present but the file isn't postscript -- any idea how safari handles that case?
long ago, we would often display binary files labeled as text/plain in UglyText format
that's what we would do if we had no sniffing
users really really hated that behavior back when it happened frequently
i'm going through www-cdf.fnal.gov/offline/PostScript/
not only due to the ugly, but also because it was unclear to them how to actually download, and often because binary files would take forever to render as text and hog lots of memory
othermaciej: yeah that matches my experience with other browsers

if we tried to view a file with the PostScript signature inline and it wasn't really PostScript, we would probably show a broken partial rendering, but would still offer the "download" and "open in external viewer" controls
so a superset of treating it as larry suggested, as application/octet-stream?
that seems better than just treating it as application/octet-stream
that amounts to treating it as application/postscript (though I'm not sure if we actually presently sniff for the PostScript signature)
is looking at MIME types

and yes, I think a broken attempt to render as PostScript is likely better than just downloading (a file that looks like a PostScript file but isn't, is most likely a damaged but perhaps still usable PostScript file)
and it is definitely better than a broken attempt to render as plain text
if a site misconfigures postscript and sends it as plain text, wouldn't they also send other binary data as plain text too?
probably
shar files, .double files, etc?
so those would show up as ugly text too?
I think the most common data types sent erroneously as plaintext are video files
unix binaries
I think the algorithm to detect unrenderable text would identify most of those things and treat them as "application/octet-stream"
(and thus cause them to download instead of displaying inline)
so not sniffing postscript wouldn't generate ugly text anyway
if postscript were removed from that table, then the user would just get the "save as" dialog
that's right, it would be the difference between "download" and "attempt to display inline as PostScript, with a control available to download"
for mac safari users
which i think is pretty unambiguously worse than having the choice between saving it or immediately viewing it
(assuming that sniffing for binary-looking stuff in text/plain was retained in general)
well, unless it isn't really postscript
in particular, for instance, users downloading videos are usually downloading porn they want to see right away, and are not trying to save them to disk
i was talking about postscript, not videos. are there video types in the table?
not yet, but adam and i were talking about adding them
since that would be a big help to users

maybe it's just Adam & etc's choice of wording

here's the bottom line:
- Not having sniffing causes some sites not to work as users expect, often enough that browsers lacking sniffing noticed.
i'm not arguing there isn't a 'market share justification', just the quantifiers in the logic
- Users complain to browser vendors or switch browsers when sites don't work.
- Browser vendors believe that not providing adequate real-world compatibility hurts their market share.

does that make sense? You might justify that "some sniffing of some times are necessary if sites that require it are widely deployed and important to users, and the consequences of sniffing are egregious enough to be noticable"
I can tell you that Web site compatibility is still a big concern for Safari, even though we have been out for 8 years and have many major companies actively looking to support us.
yes, of course "Web site compatibility" is a big concern and i'm not doubt it

i'm not doubting the steps of the logic, or your efforts
that's not the bottom line, the bottom line is this: we tried requiring that UAs not browser sniff for 19 years, and the result was that the requirement was ignored.
Our Product Marketing still cites it as a very important area for users.
no, that's hardly the bottom line of anything
so now we're trying to mitigate the damage by saying how it should be done
that is the only reason i'm doing this
i want interop

we haven't really done heads-up A/B experiments of sniffing and not sniffing to see how many more users switch to other browsers, or how many fewer adopt Safari

we are not inclined to do that level of investigation
i appreciate your efforts, but i don't think it's insulting you to question some of the conclusions you've come to

they long ago became millionaires and retired
